page.title: 13ECOLOGY IN WESTFIELD
page.content: Lolly Moor Nature Reserve is in the small village of Westfield. It used to be a fuel allotment for the poor of the parish but now it is let by the parish council to the Norfolk Naturalist Trust. The land is low lying marshland next to a tributary of the river Tud. The trees were regulary coppiced for fuel but they are now being allowed to mature. It is 5 acres in size and Mr and Mrs Keele who look after it as voluntary wardens have been there for 7 years. The different animals that inhabit the reserve include hares, field mice, bank voles, moles, stoats and squirrels. There are also 116 types of fungi, 5 types of orchids, about 10 types of butterfly and 1,000's of different insects.
